member.name: M:Au.APerf.Cpu(System.Int32)
member.summary: Executes some code in loop for the specified amount of time. It should make CPU to run at full speed.
member.param: How long to speed up CPU, milliseconds. The minimal required time probably is about 100 ms, but depends on CPU.
member.remarks:
Code speed measurements often are misleading because of variable CPU speed. Most CPU don't run at full speed when not actively used.
You can make CPU speed constant in Control Panel -> Power Options -> ... Advanced -> Processor power management -> Minimum or maximum power state. There are programs that show current CPU speed. For example HWMonitor.

member.name: P:Au.APerf.Shared
member.summary: Gets a reference to a variable in shared memory.
member.remarks: The variable can be used by multiple processes, for example to measure process startup time. Note: slow first time in process, eg 3 ms. It's because need to JIT-compile functions and open shared memory.

member.name: T:Au.ATime
member.summary: Time functions. Get time, sleep/wait, doevents.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.PerfMicroseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of microseconds elapsed since Windows startup. Uses the high-resolution system timer.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. This function is used to measure time differences with 1 microsecond precision, like var t1=ATime.PerfMicroseconds; ... var t2=ATime.PerfMicroseconds; var diff=t2-t1;. Independent of computer clock time changes. MSDN article: Acquiring high-resolution time stamps.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.PerfMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup. Uses the high-resolution system timer.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryPerformanceCounter. This function is used to measure time differences with 1 ms precision, like var t1=ATime.PerfMilliseconds; ... var t2=ATime.PerfMilliseconds; var diff=t2-t1;. The return value equals /1000 but is slightly different than of and other similar functions of this library, Windows API and .NET. Never compare times returned by different functions. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMilliseconds
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup.
member.remarks: Uses API GetTickCount64. Like , but returns a 64-bit value that does not overflow. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. When need to measure time differences with better precision, use or . Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMilliseconds32
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup.
member.remarks: Uses API GetTickCount. The same as . Returns a 32-bit value that overflows after 24.9 days. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.WinMillisecondsWithoutSleep
member.summary: Gets the number of milliseconds elapsed since Windows startup, not including the time when the computer sleeps or hibernates.
member.remarks: Uses API QueryUnbiasedInterruptTime. Uses the low-resolution system timer. Its period usually is 15.25 ms. Independent of computer clock time changes.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.Sleep(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMilliseconds milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. Or .
member.remarks: Calls . Does not process Windows messages and other events, therefore should not be used in threads with windows, timers, hooks, events or COM, unless timeMilliseconds is small. Supports APC. If the computer goes to sleep or hibernate during that time, the real time is the specified time + the sleep/hibernate time.
member.exception: timeMilliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite (-1).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.ms(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMilliseconds milliseconds. The same as .
member.exception: timeMilliseconds is negative and not Timeout.Infinite (-1).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.s(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeSeconds seconds. The same as and , but the time is specified in seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, seconds.
member.exception: timeSeconds is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.s(System.Double)
member.summary: Waits timeSeconds seconds. The same as and , but the time is specified in seconds, not milliseconds.
member.param: Time to wait, seconds. The smallest value is 0.001 (1 ms).
member.exception: timeSeconds is less than 0 or greater than 2147483 (int.MaxValue/1000, 24.8 days).

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepDoEvents(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits timeMS milliseconds. While waiting, retrieves and dispatches Windows messages and other events.
member.param: Time to wait, milliseconds. Or .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function retrieves and dispatches Windows messages, calls .NET event handlers, hook procedures, timer functions, COM/RPC, etc. Supports APC. This function can be used in threads with windows. However usually there are better ways, for example timer, other thread, async/await/Task. In some places this function does not work as expected, for example in Form/Control mouse event handlers .NET blocks other mouse events. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as . Calls API MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx and .
member.exception: timeMS is negative and not Timeout.Infinite.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepDoEvents_(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: SleepDoEvents + noSetPrecision.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.DoEvents
member.summary: Retrieves and dispatches events and Windows messages from the message queue of this thread.
member.remarks: Similar to , but more lightweight. Uses API functions PeekMessage, TranslateMessage and DispatchMessage. Be careful, this function is as dangerous as Application.DoEvents.

member.name: T:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_
member.summary: Temporarily changes the time resolution/precision of Thread.Sleep and some other functions.
member.remarks: Uses API timeBeginPeriod, which requests a time resolution for various system timers and wait functions. Actually it is the system thread scheduling timer period. Normal resolution on Windows 7-10 is 15.625 ms. It means that, for example, Thread.Sleep(1); sleeps not 1 but 1-15 ms. If you set resolution 1, it sleeps 1-2 ms. The new resolution is revoked (timeEndPeriod) when disposing the SleepPrecision_ variable or when this process ends. See example. See also . The resolution is applied to all threads and processes. Other applications can change it too. For example, often web browsers temporarily set resolution 1 ms when opening a web page. The system uses the smallest period (best resolution) that currently is set by any application. You cannot make it bigger than current value. It is not recommended to keep small period (high resolution) for a long time. It can be bad for power saving. Don't need this for ATime.SleepX and functions that use them (AMouse.Click etc). They call when the sleep time is 1-99 ms. This does not change the minimal period of and System.Windows.Forms.Timer.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls API timeBeginPeriod.
member.param: New system timer period, milliseconds. Should be 1. Other values may stuck and later cannot be made smaller due to bugs in OS or some applications; this bug would impact many functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.Dispose
member.summary: Calls API timeEndPeriod.

member.name: P:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.Current
member.summary: Gets current actual system time resolution (period). The return value usually is between 0.5 and 15.625 milliseconds. Returns 0 if fails.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.TempSet1(System.Int32)
member.summary: Temporarily sets the system wait precision to 1 ms. It will be revoked after the specified time or when this process ends. If already set, just updates the revoking time.
member.param: Revoke after this time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.ATime.SleepPrecision_.TempSet1_(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calls TempSet1 if sleepTimeMS is 1-99.
member.param: milliseconds of the caller 'sleep' function.

member.name: T:Au.ATimer
member.summary: Timer that uses API SetTimer.
member.remarks:
Similar to System.Windows.Forms.Timer, but more lightweight, for example does not create a hidden window. Use in UI threads. Does not work if this thread does not retrieve/dispatch posted messages (WM_TIMER).
Delegates of timer actions are protected from GC, even of unreferenced ATimer variables.

member.name: P:Au.ATimer.Tag
member.summary: Something to attach to this variable.

member.name: P:Au.ATimer.IsRunning
member.summary: true if the timer is started and not stopped. Note: single-period timer is automatically stopped before calling the callback function.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.After(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts one-time timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval after which will be called the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal interval is 10-20 ms.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as previous Start.
member.remarks: The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function. The callback function can start it again. If already started, this function must be called in the same thread as when started.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Every(System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts periodic timer. If already started, resets and changes its period.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal period is 10-20 ms.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as previous Start.
member.remarks: The callback function can stop the timer or restart with different period. If already started, this function must be called in the same thread as when started.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Stop
member.summary: Stops the timer.
member.exception: Called not in the same thread as Start.
member.remarks: The callback function will not be called after this. Later you can start the timer again (call or ). Don't need to call this function for single-period timers. For periodic timers it is optional; the timer stops when the thread ends. This function must be called in the same thread as Start.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Now
member.summary: Execute the timer action now.
member.remarks: Does not change any properties. Just calls the callback function. Does not handle exceptions.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.After(System.Int32,System.Action{Au.ATimer},System.Object)
member.summary: Creates and starts new one-time timer. Returns new object. Usually you don't need it.
member.param: Time interval after which will be called the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal interval is 10-20 ms.
Callback function.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.remarks: The timer will be stopped before calling the callback function. The callback function can start it again. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must must get/dispatch posted messages, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or ADialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread does not do it.

member.name: M:Au.ATimer.Every(System.Int32,System.Action{Au.ATimer},System.Object)
member.summary: Creates and starts new periodic timer. Returns new object that can be used to modify timer properties if you want to do it not in the callback function; usually don't need it.
member.param: Time interval (period) of calling the callback function, milliseconds. The actual minimal period is 10-20 ms.
Callback function.
Something to pass to the callback function as .
member.remarks: The callback function can stop the timer or restart with different period. The callback function will be called in this thread. This thread must must get/dispatch posted messages, eg call Application.Run() or Form.ShowModal() or ADialog.Show(). The callback function is not called while this thread does not do it.

member.name: T:Au.AWaitFor
member.summary: Contains functions to wait for a user-defined condition or variable.
member.remarks:
Specialized 'wait for' functions are in other classes, for example .
All 'wait for' functions have a secondsTimeout parameter. It is the maximal time to wait, seconds. If it is 0, waits infinitely. If >0, after that time interval throws . If <0, then stops waiting and returns default value of that type (false, etc).
While waiting, most functions by default don't dispatch Windows messages, events, hooks, timers, COM/RPC, etc. For example, if used in a Form/Control event handler, the form would stop responding. Use another thread, for example async/await/Task, like in the example. Or option .

member.name: T:Au.AWaitFor.Loop
member.summary: Can be used to easily implement 'wait for' functions with a timeout.
member.remarks: See examples. The code works like most 'wait for' functions of this library: on timeout throws exception, unless secondsTimeout is negative. Similar code is used by most 'wait for' functions of this library. See also ; usually it's easier; internally it uses similar code too.

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.Period
member.summary: Current period ( sleep time), milliseconds. Initially it is , optionally multiplied by constructor's options.Period/10. Default 10 ms. Then each increments it until .

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.MaxPeriod
member.summary: Maximal period ( sleep time), milliseconds. It is *50 (default 500).

member.name: P:Au.AWaitFor.Loop.TimeRemaining
member.summary: Gets or sets the remaining time, milliseconds.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Handle(System.Double,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a kernel object (event, mutex, etc).
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
One or more handles of kernel objects. Max 63.
member.returns: Returns 1-based index of the first signaled handle. Negative if abandoned mutex. On timeout returns 0 if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.exception: Failed. For example a handle is invalid.
member.remarks: Uses API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx. Alertable. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Wait_(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: Waits for a signaled kernel handle. Or just sleeps, if handles is null/empty. If flag DoEvents, dispatches received messages, hook notifications, etc. Calls API WaitForMultipleObjectsEx or MsgWaitForMultipleObjectsEx with QS_ALLINPUT. Alertable. When a handle becomes signaled, returns its 0-based index. If abandoned mutex, returns 0-based index + Api.WAIT_ABANDONED_0 (0x80). If timeMS>0, waits max timeMS and on timeout returns Api.WAIT_TIMEOUT. If failed, returns -1. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Wait_(System.Int64,Au.Types.WHFlags,System.Object,Au.Types.WaitVariable_,System.IntPtr[])
member.summary: The same as + can wait for message and variable. If msgCallback is not null, calls it when dispatching messages. If returns true, stops waiting and returns handles?.Length. If it is WPMCallback, calls it before dispatching a posted message. If it is Func{bool}, calls it after dispatching one or more messages. If stopVar is not null, when it becomes true stops waiting and returns handles?.Length + 1.

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.PostedMessage(System.Double,Au.Types.WPMCallback)
member.summary: Waits for a posted message received by this thread.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . Before dispatching a posted message, calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Does not dispatch the message if the function sets the message field = 0. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.MessagesAndCondition(System.Double,System.Func{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Waits for a variable or other condition that is changed while processing messages or other events received by this thread.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Callback function that returns true to stop waiting. More info in Remarks.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: While waiting, dispatches Windows messages etc, like . After dispatching one or more messages or other events (posted messages, messages sent by other threads, hooks, etc), calls the callback function. Stops waiting when it returns true. Similar to . Differences: 1. Always dispatches messages etc. 2. Does not call the callback function when there are no messages etc. Does not use .

member.name: M:Au.AWaitFor.Variable(System.Double,System.Boolean@,Au.Types.OWaitFor)
member.summary: Waits until a variable is set = true.
member.param: Timeout, seconds. Can be 0 (infinite), >0 (exception) or <0 (no exception). More info: [](xref:wait_timeout).
Stop waiting when this variable is set to true.
Options. If null, uses , else combines with it.
member.returns: Returns true. On timeout returns false if secondsTimeout is negative; else exception.
member.remarks: This function is useful when the variable can be changed by any thread. To wait for a variable changed while processing messages etc in this thread, it's better to use .

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs
member.summary: Allows to define custom scopes/contexts/conditions for triggers.
member.remarks:
Similar to (code like Triggers.Of.Window(...);), but allows to define any scope/condition/etc, not just the active window.
To define a scope, you create a callback function (CF) that checks some conditions and returns true to allow the trigger action to run or false to not allow. Assign the CF to some property of this class and then add the trigger, like in the examples below. The CF will be assigned to the trigger and called when need.
You may ask: why to use CF when the trigger action (TA) can do the same? 1. CF runs synchronously; if it returns false, the trigger key or mouse button message is passed to other triggers, hooks and apps. TA cannot do it reliably; it runs asynchronously, and the message is already stealed from other apps/triggers/hooks. 2. CF is faster to call. It is simply called in the same thread that processes trigger messages. TA usually runs in another thread. 3. A CF can be assigned to multiple triggers with a single line of code. Don't need to add the same code in all trigger actions.
A trigger can have up to 4 CF delegates and a window scope (Triggers.Of...). They are called in this order: CF assigned through , , window scope, , . The NextX properties assign the CF to the next single trigger. The FollowingX properties assign the CF to all following triggers until you assign another CF or null. If several are assigned, the trigger action runs only if all CF return true and the window scope matches. The XBeforeWindow properties are used only with hotkey, autotext and mouse triggers.
All CF must be as fast as possible. Slow CF can make triggers slower (or even all keyboard/mouse input); also may cause warnings and trigger failures. A big problem is the low-level hooks timeout that Windows applies to trigger hooks; see . A related problem - slow JIT and loading of assemblies, which can make the CF too slow the first time; in some rare cases may even need to preload assemblies or pre-JIT functions to avoid the timeout warning.
In CF never use functions that generate keyboard or mouse events or activate windows.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.NextTrigger
member.summary: Sets callback function for the next added trigger. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called after evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of all types.

member.summary: Sets callback function for the next added trigger. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called before evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of these types: hotkey, autotext, mouse.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.FollowingTriggers
member.summary: Sets callback function for multiple triggers added afterwards. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called after evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of all types. The value can be null.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.TriggerFuncs.FollowingTriggersBeforeWindow
member.summary: Sets callback function for multiple triggers added afterwards. If the trigger has a window scope, the callback function is called before evaluating the window. This function is used with triggers of these types: hotkey, autotext, mouse. The value can be null.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions
member.summary: Allows to set some options for multiple triggers and their actions.
member.remarks: You set options through a thread-static property . Changed options are applied to all triggers/actions added afterwards in this thread.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.Thread(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run actions always in the same dedicated thread that does not end when actions end.
member.param: A number that you want to use to identify the thread. Can be 0-127. Default 0.

Defines when to start an action if an action (other or same) is currently running in this thread. If 0 (default), don't run. If -1 (Timeout.Infinite), run when that action ends (and possibly other queed actions). If > 0, run when that action ends, if it ends within this time from now; the time is in milliseconds.
No warning when cannot start an action because an action is running and ifRunningWaitMS==0.
member.remarks: Multiple actions in same thread cannot run simultaneously. Actions in different threads can run simultaneously. There is no "end old running action" feature. If need it, use other script. Example: Triggers.Hotkey["Ctrl+M"] = o => ATask.RunWait("Other Script");. There is no "temporarily pause old running action to run new action" feature. As well as for scripts. The thread has . There are several ThreadX functions. Only the last called function is active. If none called, it is the same as called this function without arguments.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadMain
member.summary: Run trigger actions in same thread as .
member.remarks: The action must be as fast as possible, else it will block triggers etc. Use to create and show toolbars (). Rarely used for other purposes.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadNew(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run trigger actions in new threads.
member.param: Don't run if this action is already running. If false, multiple action instances can run paralelly in multiple threads.
Don't set .
member.remarks: The action can run simultaneously with other actions.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.TriggerOptions.ThreadPool(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Run trigger actions in thread pool threads.
member.param: Don't run if this action is already running. If false, multiple action instances can run paralelly in multiple threads.
member.remarks: The action can run simultaneously with other actions. May start later if the pool is busy. You should know how to use thread pool correctly. The action runs in the .NET thread pool through .

example.code: Triggers.Options.BeforeAction = o => { AOpt.Key.KeySpeed = 20; AOpt.Key.TextSpeed = 5; };

example.code: Triggers.Options.AfterAction = o => { if(o.Exception!=null) AOutput.Write(o.Exception.Message); else AOutput.Write("completed successfully"); };

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggers.DefaultPostfixChars
member.summary: Default value for the postfixChars parameter used for triggers added afterwards. Default: null.
member.remarks: If null (default), postfix characters are all except alpha-numeric (see ). The value cannot contain alpha-numeric characters (exception) and characters (triggers will not work). For Enter use \r.
member.exception: The value contains letters or digits.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggers.PostfixKey
member.summary: The postfix key for all triggers where postfix type is or (default). Can be Ctrl (default), Shift, LCtrl, RCtrl, LShift or RShift.
member.exception: The value is not Ctrl or Shift.
member.remarks: This property is applied to all triggers, not just to those added afterwards.

member.name: P:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggers.WordCharsPlus
member.summary: Additional word characters (non-delimiters). Default: null.
member.remarks: By default, only alpha-numeric characters ( returns true) are considered word characters. You can use this property to add more word characters, for example "_#". This is used to avoid activating triggers when a trigger text found inside a word. This property is applied to all triggers, not just to those added afterwards.

member.summary: If true, will select text with Shift+Left instead of erasing with Backspace. Except in console windows. Initially true if flag is set. Can be changed by a callback function, for example to use or not use Shift+Left only with some windows.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.AutotextTriggerArgs.Replace(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the user-typed text with the specified text or/and HTML.
member.param: The replacement text. Can be null.

The replacement HTML. Can be full HTML or fragment. See . Can be specified only text or only html or both. If both, will paste html in apps that support it, elsewhere text. If only html, in apps that don't support HTML will paste html as text.
member.remarks:
Options for this function can be specified when adding triggers, in the flags parameter. Or before adding triggers, with .
If the replacement text contains substring "[[|]]", removes it and moves the text cursor (caret) there with the Left key. See example. Not if html specified.
member.example:
Triggers.Autotext["#exa"] = o => o.Replace("<example>[[|]]</example>");
More examples: .

member.param: The same as with .
member.remarks:
Options for this function can be specified when adding triggers, in the flags parameter. Or before adding triggers, with . This function uses , , , .
If used flag , for label can be used first argument with prefix "!!"; else displays all string arguments.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TKFlags
member.summary: Flags of hotkey triggers.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.ShareEvent
member.summary: Allow other apps to receive the key down message too. Without this flag, other apps usually receive only modifier keys. Also, OS always receives Ctrl+Alt+Delete and some other hotkeys. To receive and block key messages is used a low-level hook. Other hooks may receive blocked messages or not, depending on when they were set.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.KeyModUp
member.summary: Run the action when the key and modifier keys are released.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.LeftMod
member.summary: The trigger works only with left-side modifier keys.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.RightMod
member.summary: The trigger works only with right-side modifier keys.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TKFlags.NoModOff
member.summary: Don't release modifier keys. Without this flag, for example if trigger is ["Ctrl+K"], when the user presses Ctrl and K down, the trigger sends Ctrl key-up event, making the key logically released, although it is still physically pressed. Then modifier keys don't interfer with the action. However functions like and (and any such functions in any app) will not know that the key is physically pressed; there is no API to get physical key state. Unreleased modifier keys will interfere with mouse functions like . Will not interfere with keyboard and clipboard functions of this library, because they release modifier keys, unless AOpt.Key.NoModOff is true. Will not interfere with functions that send text, unless AOpt.Key.NoModOff is true and AOpt.Key.TextHow is OKeyText.KeysX.. Other flags that prevent releasing modifier keys: KeyUp, ShareEvent. Then don't need this flag.

member.summary: Button for mouse click triggers.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMWheel
member.summary: Mouse wheel direction for mouse wheel triggers.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMEdge
member.summary: Screen edge for mouse edge triggers.
member.remarks: To activate a screen edge trigger, the user touches a screen edge with the mouse pointer. Each screen edge is divided into 3 parts: 1 - center 50%; 2 - left or top 25%; 3 - right or bottom 25%. Constants like TopInCenter50 specify an edge and part; the trigger works only in that part of that edge. Constants like Top specify just an edge; the trigger works in all parts of that edge.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMMove
member.summary: Mouse movement directions for mouse move triggers.
member.remarks: To activate a mouse move trigger, the user quickly moves the mouse pointer to the specified direction and back. The screen is divided into 3 parts: 1 - center 50%; 2 - left or top 25%; 3 - right or bottom 25%. Constants like UpDownInCenter50 specify a direction and screen part; the trigger works only in that screen part. Constants like UpDown specify just a direction; the trigger works in whole screen.

member.name: T:Au.Triggers.TMScreen
member.summary: Screen index for mouse triggers.

member.name: F:Au.Triggers.TWFlags.LaterCallFunc
member.summary: When using the later parameter, call the currently active Triggers.FuncOf functions on "later" events too. If the function returns false, the action will not run. The function runs synchronously in the same thread that called . The action runs asynchronously in another thread, which is slower to start. As always, Triggers.FuncOf functions must not contain slow code; should take less than 10 ms.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.SimulateActiveNew(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Simulates event "activated new window" as if the the specified window is that window.
member.remarks: This function usually is used to run ActiveNew triggers for a window created before calling . Here "run triggers" means "compare window properties etc with those specified in triggers and run actions of triggers that match". Normally such triggers don't run because the window is considered old. This function runs triggers as it was a new window. Triggers like ActiveNew and ActiveOnce will run once, as usually. This function must be called while the main triggers thread is in , for example from another trigger action. It is asynchronous (does not wait). If you call this function from another trigger action (hotkey etc), make sure the window trigger action runs in another thread or can be queed. Else both actions cannot run simultaneously. See example.

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.SimulateVisibleNew(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Simulates event "visible new window" as if the specified window is that window. Similar to .

member.name: M:Au.Triggers.WindowTriggers.LogEvents(System.Boolean,System.Func{Au.AWnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Starts or stops to log (write in output) window events that can help to create or debug window triggers.
member.param: Start (true) or stop.
An optional callback function that can be used to reduce noise, eg skip tooltip windows. Return true to skip that window.
member.remarks:
For primary trigger events is logged this info:
Time milliseconds. Shows only the remainder of dividing by 10 seconds, therefore it starts from 0 again when reached 9999 (9 seconds and 999 milliseconds).
Event (see ).
Letters for window state etc:
A - the window is active.
H - the window is invisible (!).
C - the window is cloaked ().
O - the window is considered old, ie created before calling .
T - the even has been detected using a timer, which means slower response time. Else detected using a hook.
Window (handle, class, name, program, rectangle).
Colors are used for window event types used for primary triggers: blue if activated; green if became visible; yellow if name changed. For "later" events is logged time, event and window. Black, tab-indented. Only events that are specified in triggers. When a trigger is activated, the event type is red.

example.code: Triggers.Window.LogEvents(true, o => 0 != o.ClassNameIs("*tooltip*", "SysShadow", "#32774", "TaskList*"));

member.name: T:Au.AWnd
member.summary: A variable of AWnd type represents a window or control. It is a window handle, also known as HWND.
member.remarks:
AWnd functions can be used with windows and controls of any process/thread. Also can be used with .NET form/control and WPF window class variables, like AWnd w=form.Hwnd(); w.Method(...);.
There are two main types of windows - top-level windows and controls. Controls are child windows of top-level windows.
More functions are in the nested classes - , etc. They are used mostly in programming, rarely in automation scripts.
What happens when an AWnd function fails: - Functions that get window properties don't throw exceptions. They return false/0/null/empty. Most of them support , and it is mentioned in function documentation. - Many functions that change window properties throw exception. Exceptions are listed in function documentation. Almost all these functions throw only . - Other functions that change window properties return false. They are more often used in programming than in automation scripts. - When a 'find' function does not find the window or control, it returns default(AWnd) (window handle 0). Then will return true. - If a function does not follow these rules, it is mentioned in function documentation.
Many functions fail if the window's process has a higher [](xref:uac) integrity level (aministrator, uiAccess) than this process, unless this process has uiAccess level. Especially the functions that change window properties. Some functions that still work: Activate, ActivateL, ShowMinimized, ShowNotMinimized, ShowNotMinMax, Close.
The AWnd type can be used with native Windows API functions without casting. Use AWnd for the parameter type in the declaration, like [DllImport(...)] static extern bool NativeFunction(AWnd hWnd, ...).
See also: MSDN article Window Features.

member.name: T:Au.AWnd.More
member.summary: Miscellaneous window-related functions and classes. Rarely used, or useful only for programmers.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.PostThreadMessage(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Posts a message to the message queue of the specified thread. Of this thread if threadId is 0. Calls API PostThreadMessage. Returns false if failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.WaitForAnActiveWindow
member.summary: Waits while there is no active window. It sometimes happens after closing, minimizing or switching the active window, briefly until another window becomes active. Waits max 500 ms, then returns false if there is no active window. Processes Windows messages that are in the message queue of this thread. Don't need to call this after calling functions of this library.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.EnableActivate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Temporarily enables this process to activate windows with API SetForegroundWindow. Returns false if fails.
member.param: Process id. If not 0, enables that process to activate windows too. If -1, all processes will be enabled.
member.remarks: In some cases you may need this function because Windows often disables API SetForegroundWindow to not allow background applications to activate windows while the user is working (using keyboard/mouse) with the currently active window. Then SetForegroundWindow usually just makes the window's taskbar button flash. Usually you don't call SetForegroundWindow directly. It is called by some other functions. Don't need to call this function before calling and other functions of this library that activate windows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.RegisterWindowClass(System.String,Au.Types.WNDPROC,Au.Types.RWCEtc)
member.summary: Registers new window class in this process.
member.param: Class name.

Delegate of a window procedure. See Window Procedures.
Use null when you need a different delegate (method or target object) for each window instance; create windows with or . If not null, it must be a static method; create windows with any other function, including API CreateWindowEx.

Can be used to specify API WNDCLASSEX fields. To set cursor use field mCursor (standard cursor) or hCursor (native handle of a custom cursor). If null, this function sets arrow cursor and style CS_VREDRAW | CS_HREDRAW.
member.exception: wndProc is an instance method. Must be static method or null. If need instance method, use null here and pass wndProc to .
The class already registered with this function and different wndProc (another method or another target object).
Failed, for example if the class already exists and was registered not with this function.
member.remarks: Calls API RegisterClassEx. The window class is registered until this process ends. Don't need to unregister. If called next time for the same window class, does nothing if wndProc is equal to the previous (or both null). Then ignores etc. Throws exception if different. Thread-safe. Protects the wndProc delegate from GC.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.CreateWindow(Au.Types.WNDPROC,System.Boolean,System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WS,Au.Types.WSE,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.AWnd,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates native/unmanaged window (API CreateWindowEx) and sets its window procedure.
member.param: Window procedure.

Protect wndProc from GC (garbage collector) until the window is destroyed (message WM_NCDESTROY recived or thread ended). In some cases it may prevent destroying the window until thread ends, and it can be a big memory leak. For example WPF then does not destroy HwndHost-ed controls. Then let keepAlive=false and manually manage wndProc lifetime, for example keep it as a field of the wrapper class.
member.remarks:
If the class was registered with with null wndProc, the wndProc function will receive all messages. Else will not receive messages sent before CreateWindowEx returns (WM_CREATE etc).
To destroy the window can be used any function, including API DestroyWindow, , , API WM_CLOSE.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.CreateWindow(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WS,Au.Types.WSE,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.AWnd,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates native/unmanaged window.
member.remarks: Calls API CreateWindowEx. To destroy the window can be used any function, including API DestroyWindow, , , API WM_CLOSE.

member.remarks: Styles: WS_POPUP, WS_EX_NOACTIVATE. To destroy the window can be used any function, including API DestroyWindow, , , API WM_CLOSE.

member.summary: Creates native/unmanaged message-only window and sets its window procedure.
member.param: Window class name.
member.remarks: Styles: WS_POPUP, WS_EX_NOACTIVATE. Calls with keepAlive=true.

member.exception: Failed to get rectangle, probably invalid window handle.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.SavedRect.NormalizeRect
member.summary: Gets real rectangle for restoring saved window rectangle.
member.remarks:
It is recommended to call this before creating window, and create window with the returned rectangle. Also set maximized state if . If it is not possible, can be called later, for example when window is created but still invisible. However then possible various problems, for example may need to set window rectangle two times, because the window may be for example DPI-scaled when moving to another screen etc.
This function ensures the window is in screen, ensures correct size when screen DPI changed, etc.

member.summary: Calls . If it returns true, sets form bounds = , maximizes if need, StartPosition=Manual, and returns true. Call this function before showing form, for example in constructor.
member.param: String created by .
If not null, called when closing the window. Receives string for saving. Can save it in registry, file, anywhere.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.More.SavedRect.Restore(System.Windows.Window,System.String,System.Action{System.String})

member.param: String created by .

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.Is0
member.summary: Returns true if the window handle is 0 (this variable == default(AWnd)).

example.code: AWnd w = AWnd.Find("Window*"); if(w.Is0) { AOutput.Write("window not found"); return; }

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsAlive
member.summary: Returns true if the window exists (the window handle is valid). Returns false if the handle is 0 or invalid. Invalid non-0 handle usually means that the window is closed/destroyed.
member.remarks: Calls and API IsWindow. Although an AWnd variable holds a window handle, which is like a reference to a window, it does not prevent closing that window and making the handle invalid. After closing the window, the OS can even assign the same handle value to a new window, although normally it can happen only after long time. Use this carefully with windows of other applications or threads. The window can be closed at any moment, even when your thread is still in this function.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsVisible
member.summary: Returns true if the window is visible. Returns false if is invisible or is a child of invisible parent. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.remarks:
Calls API IsWindowVisible. Does not call .
Even when this function returns true, the window may be actually invisible. It can be cloaked, on an inactive Windows 10 virtual desktop (cloaked), inactive Windows Store app (cloaked), transparent, zero-size, minimized, off-screen, covered by other windows or can have zero-size window region.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsVisibleAndNotCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if returns true and returns false.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.IsVisibleIn_(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns true if this window is visible in the specified parent or ancestor window. Like , but does not check the visibility of the specified parent/ancestor window.
member.param: Parent or ancestor window.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Show(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window.
member.remarks: Does not activate/deactivate/zorder. This window can be of any thread. If you know it is of this thread, use . This function calls it.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ShowL(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shows (if hidden) or hides this window.
member.returns: Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.remarks:
Does not activate/deactivate/zorder.
There are two similar functions to show/hide a window: - is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It calls ShowL, and throws exception if it fails. Adds a small delay if the window is of another thread. - ShowL is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. It is more lightweight. Does not throw exceptions. Does not add a delay. But both functions can be used with windows of any thread.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.IsEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true if the window is enabled for mouse and keyboard input. Returns false if disabled. Also false if failed (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Check whether all ancestors of this control are enabled too. If false (default), this function simply calls API IsWindowEnabled, which usualy returns true for controls in disabled windows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Enable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables. Calls API EnableWindow.
member.param: Enable or disable.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsCloakedGetState
member.summary: Gets the cloaked state. Returns 0 if not cloaked or if failed. Else returns flags: 1 cloaked by its application, 2 cloaked by Windows, 4 cloaked because its owner window is cloaked. On Windows 7 returns 0 because there is no "cloaked window" feature.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsCloaked
member.summary: Returns true if the window is cloaked. Returns false if not cloaked or if failed. On Windows 7 returns false because there is no "cloaked window" feature. Windows 10 uses window cloaking mostly to hide windows on inactive desktops. Windows 8 - mostly to hide Windows Store app windows.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsMinimized

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsMaximized
member.summary: Returns true if maximized, false if not. Also returns false when fails (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports . Calls API IsZoomed.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Internal_._EnableActivate_SendKey(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Sends a key (VK_0 up). It allows to activate now. Later this process can always activate easily (without key etc). It works even with higher IL windows. Don't know why is this behavior. Tested on all OS from XP to 10. Does not work if the foreground process has higher UAC IL.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Internal_.SubclassUnsafe(Au.AWnd,Au.Types.WNDPROC)
member.summary: Replaces window procedure (SetWindowLongPtr). Returns previous window procedure. The caller must protect the delegate from GC.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Internal_.FromObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Converts object to AWnd. Object can contain null, AWnd, Control, or System.Windows.DependencyObject (must be in element 0 of object[]). Avoids loading Forms and WPF dlls when not used.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Internal_.ToWpfElement(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: If w is handle of a WPF element (Window, Popup, HwndHost-ed control, HwndSource.RootVisual), returns that element, else null. Slow if HwndHost-ed control. w can be default.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Activate_(Au.AWnd.Internal_.ActivateFlags)
member.summary: Activates this window (brings to the foreground). The same as , but has some options. Returns false if does not activate because of flag IgnoreIfNoActivateStyleEtc.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Activate
member.summary: Activates this window. Also makes it visible and not minimized. The active window is in the foreground and receives keyboard and mouse input.
member.remarks: Activating a window usually also uncloaks it, for example switches to its virtual desktop on Windows 10. Fails (throws exception) if cannot activate this window, except: - If this is a control. Then activates its top-level parent window. - If this is . Then just deactivates the currently active window. - When the target application instead activates another window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ActivateL
member.summary: Lightweight version of . Just calls , API SetForegroundWindow and makes sure that it actually worked, but does not check whether it activated exactly this window. No exceptions, does not unhide, does not restore minimized, does not check is it a top-level window or control, etc. Returns false if fails.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Focus
member.summary: Sets the keyboard input focus to this control. Also activetes its top-level parent window (see ).
member.remarks: The control can belong to any process/thread. With controls of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Works not with all windows. For example, does not work with Windows Store apps. Then use . Can instead focus a child control. For example, if this is a ComboBox, it will focus its child Edit control. Then does not throw exception. This can be control or top-level window. Top-level windows also can have focus.
member.exception: - Invalid handle. - Disabled. - Failed to set focus. - Failed to activate parent window. Fails to set focus when the target process is admin or uiAccess and this process isn't. See [](xref:uac).

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.Focused
member.summary: Gets the control or window that has the keyboard input focus.
member.remarks: The control/window can belong to any process/thread. With controls/windows of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls API GetGUIThreadInfo.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.IsFocused
member.summary: Returns true if this is the control or window that has the keyboard input focus.
member.remarks: This control/window can belong to any process/thread. With controls/windows of this thread you can use the more lightweight function . Calls .

member.name: T:Au.AWnd.ThisThread
member.summary: Functions that can be used only with windows/controls of this thread.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ThisThread.Focus(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Calls API SetFocus. It sets the keyboard input focus to the specified control or window, which must be of this thread. Returns false if fails. Supports .
member.remarks: Fails if the control/window belongs to another thread or is invalid or disabled. Can instead focus a child control. For example, if ComboBox, will focus its child Edit control. Then returns true.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ThisThread.Focused
member.summary: Gets the focused control or window of this thread.
member.remarks: Calls API GetFocus.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ThisThread.IsFocused(Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns true if w is the focused control or window of this thread.
member.remarks: Calls API GetFocus.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ThisThread.Active
member.summary: Gets the active window of this thread. Calls API GetActiveWindow.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.MoveL(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Au.Types.SWPFlags)
member.summary: Moves and resizes.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max, does not support SWP flags. This function is more lightweight, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE|swpFlagsToAdd. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.MoveL(Au.Types.RECT,Au.Types.SWPFlags)
member.summary: Moves and resizes. Same as .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.MoveL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Moves.
member.remarks:
See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is more lightweight, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOSIZE|NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .
For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ResizeL(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Resizes.
member.remarks: See also . It is better to use in automation scripts, with windows of any process/thread. It throws exceptions, supports optional/reverse/fractional/workarea coordinates, restores if min/max. This function is more lightweight, it just calls API SetWindowPos with flags NOMOVE|NOZORDER|NOOWNERZORDER|NOACTIVATE. It is better to use in programming, with windows of current thread. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.AScreen)
member.summary: Moves and/or resizes.
member.param: Left. If default(Coord), does not move in X axis.
Top. If default(Coord), does not move in Y axis.
Width. If default(Coord), does not change width.
Height. If default(Coord), does not change height.
x y width height are relative to the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
x y width height are relative to this screen or its work area. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window. Example: AScreen.Index(1).
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client area coordinates. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Move(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.AScreen)
member.summary: Moves.
member.param: Left. If default(Coord), does not move in X axis.
Top. If default(Coord), does not move in Y axis.
x y are relative to the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
x y are relative to this screen or its work area. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window. Example: AScreen.Index(1).
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. For top-level windows use screen coordinates. For controls - direct parent client coordinates. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Resize(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,System.Boolean,Au.AScreen)
member.summary: Resizes.
member.param: Width. If default(Coord), does not change width.
Height. If default(Coord), does not change height.
For etc use width/height of the work area. Not used when this is a child window.
For Coord.Fraction etc use width/height of this screen. Default - primary. Not used when this is a child window. Example: AScreen.Index(1).
member.remarks: Also restores the visible top-level window if it is minimized or maximized. With windows of current thread usually it's better to use .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.MoveInScreen(Au.Types.Coord,Au.Types.Coord,Au.AScreen,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window to coordinates x y in specified screen, and ensures that entire window is in screen.
member.param: X coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. You also can use etc.
Y coordinate in the specified screen. If default(Coord) - screen center. You also can use etc.
Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window. Example: AScreen.Index(1).
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
If part of window is not in screen, move and/or resize it so that entire window would be in screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately, except when moving maximized to another screen.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.EnsureInScreen(Au.AScreen,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves this window if need, to ensure that entire window is in screen.
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window.
Use the work area, not whole screen. Default true.
member.remarks: If the window is maximized, minimized or hidden, it will have the new position and size when restored, not immediately.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.MoveToScreenCenter(Au.AScreen)
member.summary: Moves this window to the center of the screen.
member.param: Move to this screen (see ). If default, uses screen of this window.
member.remarks: Calls ShowNotMinMax(true) and MoveInScreen(default, default, screen, true).

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.Screen
member.summary: Gets of the screen that contains this window (the biggest part of it) or is nearest to it. If this window handle is default(AWnd) or invalid, gets the primary screen. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderAbove(Au.AWnd,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Places this window above window w in the Z order.
member.param: Change Z order of owner window too.
member.remarks: Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. If w is default(AWnd), calls . Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; it depends on many documented and undocumented conditions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderBelow(Au.AWnd,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Places this window below window w in the Z order.
member.param: Change Z order of owner window too.
member.remarks: Also can make this window topmost or non-topmost, depending on where w is in the Z order. This window and w can be both top-level windows or both controls of same parent. If w is default(AWnd), calls . Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; its behavior depends on many documented and undocumented conditions and changes with new OS versions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderTop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Places this window or control at the top of the Z order. Does not activate. If the window was topmost, it will be at the top of topmost windows, else at the top of non-topmost windows.
member.param: Change Z order of owner window too.
member.remarks: Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; its behavior depends on many documented and undocumented conditions and changes with new OS versions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderBottom
member.summary: Places this window or control at the bottom of the Z order. If the window was topmost, makes it and its owner window non-topmost.
member.remarks: Changes Z order of owner window too. Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; its behavior depends on many documented and undocumented conditions and changes with new OS versions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderTopmost(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this window topmost (always on top of non-topmost windows in the Z order). Does not activate.
member.param: Change Z order of owner window too.
member.remarks: This cannot be a control. Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; its behavior depends on many documented and undocumented conditions and changes with new OS versions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ZorderNoTopmost(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Makes this window non-topmost.
member.param: Also place this window below the active nontopmost window in the Z order, unless the active window is this or owner.
member.remarks: Changes Z order of owner window too. This cannot be a control. Uses API SetWindowPos. It may refuse to change Z order of top-level windows; its behavior depends on many documented and undocumented conditions and changes with new OS versions; can even return true when failed. Supports .

member.summary: If window class name matches one of strings in classNames, returns 1-based string index. Else returns 0. Also returns 0 if fails to get class name (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.Name
member.summary: Gets name. Returns "" if no name. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Top-level window name usually its title bar text. Control name usually is its text that does not change, for example button or static (label) control text. Unlike , this function usually does not get variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. Calls (false, true).

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.NameIs(System.String[])
member.summary: If window name matches one of strings in names, returns 1-based string index. Else returns 0. Also returns 0 if fails to get name (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Window names. Case-insensitive wildcard. See . The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.NameTL_
member.summary: Gets window name using API InternalGetWindowText. The same as GetText(false, false). This should be a top-level window, because does not process ampersands.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ControlText
member.summary: Gets control text. Returns "" if no text. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports .
member.remarks: Unlike , this function prefers variable text, for example Edit control editable text, ComboBox control selected item text, status bar text. For controls that cannot have such text (eg button, static), it usually gets the same text as Name. For example button and static (label) controls. Much slower than Name. Fails if the window is hung. Calls (true, false).

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetText(System.Nullable{System.Boolean},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets window/control name or control text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the window is closed. Supports . This is a low-level function. You can instead use and .
member.param: How to get text: - false - use API InternalGetWindowText. This is used by . - true - use API WM_GETTEXT. It is slow and prefers editable text. This is used by . Fails if the window is hung. - null - try InternalGetWindowText. If it gets "" and this is a control, then try WM_GETTEXT.
Remove the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key. Removes only if this is a control (has style WS.CHILD). Calls .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd._GetTextFast(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Calls API InternalGetWindowText. If it fails, and getControlTextIfEmpty==true, and this is a control, calls _GetTextSlow, which uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd._GetTextSlow
member.summary: Gets text. Returns "" if it is empty. Returns null if fails, eg if the control is destroyed or its thread is hung. Supports . Uses WM_GETTEXT.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Sets window/control name or control text.
member.param: Text. Can be null, it is the same as "".
member.remarks: Uses API WM_SETTEXT. Top-level window name usually its title bar text. For variable-text controls (edit, combo box, status bar, ...) this usually is the text that would get. For other controls (button, static, ...) and top-level windows this usually is the text that would get.
member.exception: Failed, for example the window is closed.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.NameAcc
member.summary: Gets of the accessible object (role WINDOW) of this window or control. Returns "" if the object has no name or failed to get it. Returns null if invalid window handle.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.NameWinforms
member.summary: Gets Control.Name property of a .NET Windows Forms control. Returns null if it is not a Windows Forms control or if fails.

remarks.note: Use this with controls of other processes. Don't use with your controls, when you have a Control object.
Slow when getting names of multiple controls in a window. Instead create an instance and call its method for each control.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ProgramName
member.summary: Gets filename of process executable file, like "notepad.exe". Return null if fails.
member.remarks: Calls and . This function is much slower than getting window name or class name. Don't use code like if(w.ProgramName=="A" || w.ProgramName=="B"). Instead use var s=w.ProgramName; if(s=="A" || s=="B").

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ProgramNameIs(System.String[])
member.summary: If window program name matches one of strings in programNames, returns 1-based string index. Else returns 0. Also returns 0 if fails to get program name (probably window closed or 0 handle). Supports .
member.param: Program names, like "notepad.exe". Case-insensitive wildcard. See . The array and strings cannot be null.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ProgramPath
member.summary: Gets full path of process executable file. Return null if fails.
member.remarks: Calls and . This function is much slower than getting window name or class name. Don't use code like if(w.ProgramPath=="A" || w.ProgramPath=="B"). Instead use var s=w.ProgramPath; if(s=="A" || s=="B").

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.ProgramDescription
member.summary: Gets description of process executable file. Return null if fails.
member.remarks: Calls and . This function is slow. Much slower than .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Close(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Closes the window. Returns true if successfuly closed or if it was already closed (the handle is 0 or invalid) or if noWait==true.
member.param: If true, does not wait until the window is closed. If false, waits about 1 s (depends on window type etc) until the window is destroyed or disabled.

If false (default), uses API message WM_CLOSE. If true, uses API message WM_SYSCOMMAND SC_CLOSE, like when the user clicks the X button in the title bar. Most windows can be closed with any of these messages, but some respond properly only to one of them. For example, some applications on WM_CLOSE don't exit, although the main window is closed. Some applications don't respond to WM_SYSCOMMAND if it is posted soon after opening the window, for example Internet Explorer.
member.remarks: The window may refuse to be closed. For example, it may be hung, or hide itself instead, or display a "Save?" message box, or is a dialog without X button, or just need more time to close it. If the window is of this thread, just calls or (if noWait==true) and returns true.

example.code: //close all Notepad windows AWnd.FindAll("* Notepad", "Notepad").ForEach(t => t.Close());

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ChildFinder._FindInList(Au.AWnd,Au.AWnd._WndList,System.Action{Au.AWnd})
member.summary: Returns index of matching element or -1. Returns -1 if using getAll.

List of AWnd. Does not dispose it.
If not null, calls it for all matching and returns -1.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ChildFinder.IsMatch(Au.AWnd,Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Returns true if control c properties match the specified properties.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.Child(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.AWnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds a child control and returns its handle as AWnd.
member.returns: Returns default(AWnd) if not found. See also: , .
member.param:
Control name. String format: [](xref:wildcard_expression). null means 'can be any'. "" means 'no name'.
By default to get control names this function uses . Can start with these prefix strings: - "***text " - use . Slower and less reliable because can get editable text. If a character can be underlined with Alt, insert '&' before it. - "***accName " - use . Slower. - "***wfName " - use .NET Forms control name (see ). Slower and can fail because of [](xref:uac). - "***id " like "***id 15" - use control id (). See also .
Control class name. String format: [](xref:wildcard_expression). null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".
Callback function. Called for each matching control. It can evaluate more properties of the control and return true when they match. Example: also: t => t.IsEnabled
0-based index of matching control. For example, if 1, the function skips the first matching control and returns the second.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
- name starts with "***", but the prefix is invalid. - cn is "". To match any, use null. - Invalid wildcard expression ("**options " or regular expression).
member.remarks: To create code for this function, use dialog "Find window or control".

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.HasChild(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.AWnd,System.Boolean},System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns true if this window contains the specified control. Calls .
Using this function many times with same parameters is inefficient. Instead create new and call or . See example.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.HasChild(Au.AWnd.ChildFinder)
member.summary: Returns true if this window contains the specified control. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.HasAcc(Au.AAcc.Finder)
member.summary: Returns true if this window contains the specified accessible object. Calls .

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ChildById(System.Int32,Au.Types.WCFlags)
member.summary: Finds a child control by its id and returns its handle as AWnd.
member.returns: Returns default(AWnd) if not found. See also: , .
member.param: Control id.
This function supports flags DirectChild and HiddenToo. If both are set, it is much faster because uses API GetDlgItem. Else uses API EnumChildWindows, like .
member.remarks:
To create code for this function, use dialog "Find window or control".
Not all controls have a useful id. If control id is not unique or is different in each window instance, this function is not useful.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ChildAll(System.String,System.String,Au.Types.WCFlags,System.Func{Au.AWnd,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Finds all matching child controls. Returns List containing 0 or more control handles as AWnd. Everything except the return type is the same as with .
member.remarks: In the returned list, hidden controls (when using WCFlags.HiddenToo) are always after visible controls.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.ChildFast(System.String,System.String,Au.AWnd)
member.summary: Finds a direct child control and returns its handle as AWnd.
member.returns: Returns default(AWnd) if not found. See also: , . Supports .
member.param: Name. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported. null means 'can be any'. "" means 'no name'. Must include the invisible '&' characters that are used to underline keyboard shortcuts with the Alt key.
Class name. Full, case-insensitive. Wildcard etc not supported. null means 'can be any'. Cannot be "".
If used, starts searching from the next control in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API FindWindowEx. Faster than , which uses API EnumChildWindows. Can be used only when you know full name and/or class name. Finds hidden controls too.

member.name: T:Au.AWnd.GetWnd
member.summary: Static functions of this class are used to get special windows (used like AWnd w = AWnd.GetWnd.Top;) and all windows. Instances of this class are used to get related windows and controls, like AWnd w2 = w1.Get.FirstChild; (here w1 is an AWnd variable).

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Children(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets child controls, including all descendants. Returns array containing 0 or more control handles as AWnd.
member.param: Need only visible controls.
Place all array elements of hidden controls at the end of the array.
Need only direct children, not all descendants.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
member.remarks: Calls API EnumChildWindows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Children(System.Collections.Generic.List{Au.AWnd}@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets child controls, including all descendants.
member.param: Receives window handles as AWnd. If null, this function creates new List, else clears before adding items.
Need only visible controls.
Place all array elements of hidden controls at the end of the array.
Need only direct children, not all descendants.
member.exception: This variable is invalid (window not found, closed, etc).
member.remarks: Use this overload to avoid much garbage when calling frequently with the same List variable. Other overload always allocates new array. This overload in most cases reuses memory allocated for the list variable.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.AllWindows(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows. Returns array containing window handles as AWnd.
member.param: Need only visible windows. Note: this function does not check whether windows are cloaked, as it is rather slow. Use if need.
Place hidden windows at the end of the array. If false, the order of array elements matches the Z order. Not used when onlyVisible is true.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumWindows. The array can be bigger than you expect, because there are many invisible windows, tooltips, etc. See also . Skips message-only windows; use if need. On Windows 8 and later may skip Windows Store app Metro-style windows (on Windows 10 few such windows exist). It happens if this program does not have disableWindowFiltering true in its manifest and is not uiAccess; to find such windows you can use . Tip: To get top-level and child windows in single array: var a = AWnd.GetWnd.Root.Get.Children();.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.AllWindows(System.Collections.Generic.List{Au.AWnd}@,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows.
member.param: Receives window handles as AWnd. If null, this function creates new List, else clears before adding items.
member.remarks: Use this overload to avoid much garbage when calling frequently with the same List variable. Other overload always allocates new array. This overload in most cases reuses memory allocated for the list variable.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.ThreadWindows(System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows of a thread. Returns array containing 0 or more window handles as AWnd.
member.param: Unmanaged thread id. See , . If 0, throws exception. If other invalid value (ended thread?), returns empty list. Supports .
Need only visible windows.
Place all array elements of hidden windows at the end of the array, even if the hidden windows are before some visible windows in the Z order.
member.remarks: Calls API EnumThreadWindows.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.ThreadWindows(System.Collections.Generic.List{Au.AWnd}@,System.Int32,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets top-level windows of a thread.
member.remarks: This overload can be used to avoid much garbage when caling frequently.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Top
member.summary: Gets the first top-level window in the Z order.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Top2(Au.AWnd@)
member.summary: Finds and returns the first non-topmost window in the Z order.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Root
member.summary: Calls API GetDesktopWindow. It gets the virtual parent window of all top-level windows.

remarks.note: It is not the desktop window (see ) that displays icons and wallpaper.

member.name: P:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.ShellWindow
member.summary: Calls API GetShellWindow. It gets a window of the shell process (usually process "explorer", class name "Progman"). Returns default(AWnd) if there is no shell process, for example Explorer process killed/crashed and still not restarted, or if using a custom shell that does not register a shell window.
member.remarks: It can be the window that contains desktop icons (see ) or other window of the same thread.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.Desktop(Au.AWnd@,Au.AWnd@)
member.summary: Gets the desktop window and its child control that displays desktop icons and wallpaper. Returns false if fails.
member.param: Receives the desktop window. Class name "Progman" or "WorkerW".
Receives the control of "SysListView32" class that contains icons and wallpaper.
member.remarks: This function is not very reliable. May stop working on a new Windows version or don't work with a custom shell. Fails if there is no shell process, for example Explorer process killed/crashed and still not restarted, or if using a custom shell that does not register a shell window.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.IsMainWindow(Au.AWnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns true if window w is considered a main window, ie probably is in the Windows taskbar. Returns false if it is invisible, cloaked, owned, toolwindow, menu, etc.
member.param: On Windows 10 include (return true for) windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps if possible; read more: .
Return false if w is minimized.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.MainWindows(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets main windows, ie those that probably are in the Windows taskbar. Returns array containing 0 or more AWnd.
member.param: On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps if possible; read more: .
member.remarks: Uses . Does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar.

member.name: M:Au.AWnd.GetWnd.NextMain(Au.AWnd,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Gets next window in the Z order, skipping invisible and other windows that probably are not in the Windows taskbar. Returns default(AWnd) if there are no such windows.
member.param: Start from this window. If default(AWnd), starts from the top of the Z order.
On Windows 10 include windows on all virtual desktops. On Windows 8 include Windows Store apps if possible; read more: .
Skip minimized windows.
If w is not default(AWnd) and there are no matching windows after it, retry from the top of the Z order. Then can return w.
member.remarks: Uses . This function is quite slow. Does not match the order of buttons in the Windows taskbar.
